If you keep increasing the pressure, eventually what happens is that at a high enough pressure, the atoms making up the Hydrogen(2) and Oxygen(1) ("Water" as we know it) will start to fuse. Nuclear fusion. Stars do this all the time, it's how the heavier elements are made.

Probably, something else happens before that extreme stage, but that's definitely the "last way out" for the atoms inside.

Fluids compress a little bit, and under very high pressure (at room temperature) H₂O will turn into various other forms of ice with different crystalline structures than Ice I (normal, standard pressure, ice).

At higher temperatures, it would become a supercritical fluid, a state that is somewhere between liquid and gas. Or, more specifically, where the line between liquid and gas is blurred.

Google "Water phase diagram" for some charts showing where these changes take place.
